Description: Circular game piece or counter; domed on one side and flat on other, made of dark blue glass.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Redpath Museum, Montreal. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Glass ‘game counter’ made from recycled fragments of monochrome transparent glass of the Roman period. Such counters became popular during the 1st century AD in Pompeii, but are also known from 2nd century AD sites, where they were used as counters, but also accounting tallies and as decorative elements within furniture, architecture, jewellery or metal vessels (Cool 2016, 231-239). Cool, H. E. M. 2016. The small finds and vessel glass from Insula VI.1 Pompeii: Excavations 1995-2006. Oxford: Archaeopress, Roman Archaeology 17.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (TH.27)
